thread.title: Smith expecting big things from Reds
thread.title_full: Smith expecting big things from Reds

title: Smith expecting big things from Reds
text:
Source: FOX SPORTS GEORGE Smith is back — but not as we’ve seen him before. 
After a three-year absence, the Australian and ACT Brumbies great — who won an astonishing 10 Brett Robinson Medals as the club’s best player — arrived at Ballymore on Monday for his first day as a Queensland Reds player. 
The sight of Smith wearing red should warm the hearts of disgruntled Queensland supporters all over the state and, indeed, the country for his record is second to none. 
His arrival has, however, for the time being been slightly overshadowed by Sunday night’s news that returning backrower Scott Higginbotham was arrested by Queensland Police on Saturday night and has subsequently been stood down by the club until the incident is investigated. 
But if there was ever a man for a crisis, Smith is it. George Smith at his first Queensland Reds training session. Source: News Corp Australia 
The 36-year-old is a former Wallabies captain, has 112 Test caps to his name, two Super Rugby titles and was just recently named in the Japan Top League’s team of the season which followed his players’ player award in the Aviva Premiership. 
He even helped undefeated England coach Eddie Jones at the start of his coaching reign, appearing at England training sessions working, in particular, with the nation’s backrowers. 
But despite his impressive resume, Smith isn’t taking his position in the side for granted. 
“My expectations are to play within this team and perform well within this team,” Smith told foxsports.com.au. 
“First and foremost I’m a rugby player and I need to perform within this team and earn the right to be within the squad. 
“But no, I haven’t spoken about playing time. As a rugby player you want to be playing every match.” A photo posted by David Pocock (@davidpocock) on Jan 29, 2017 at 12:59am PST 
Smith’s arrival at the club comes just a week after helping Suntory Sungoliath, together with Reds teammate Hendrik Tui, to the All-Japan Championship Final, as they defeated Panasonic Wild Knights 15-10. 
He also showed up David Pocock in the process, making a crucial pilfer late in the match to help seal the club’s 17th straight win. 
Despite not having a break for more than a year, Smith said that he is excited to be returning to Super Rugby and said that the hardest challenge at the moment is surviving the hot Brisbane conditions after playing through the Japanese winter. 
“I feel good,” Smith said. 
“Mentally I’m really excited about the season ahead. I always knew that I was coming back to play rugby here with the Reds, so it hasn’t been much of a mental effort in readjusting and focusing on this competition. 
“I’ve just come off the back of a really successful season with Suntory in Japan. 
“Pretty confident with the way I played throughout that time over there and I’ve parked all that, and now the focus is with the Reds. 
“I had my first session here at the Reds this morning. In this heat it’s quite difficult, but I’m really enjoying it so far.” George Smith of the Wallabies in action during the Tri Nations in 2005. Source: FOX SPORTS 
After three years of disappointment and frustration, 2017 promises plenty for Reds fans. 
As well as Smith, first-year head coach Nick Stiles, who took over as co-head coach together with Matt O’Connor after Richard Graham’s early-season sacking, has put together the best list of players in Australia’s conference, signing Wallabies captain Stephen Moore from the Brumbies, and bringing back Leroy Houston and Higginbotham. 
But it’s not just the new additions that will add plenty to the squad, with Wallabies Kane Douglas, James Slipper and Karmichael Hunt set to start the season after missing the majority of 2016. 
Smith sees potential in the group, but is experienced enough to know that promise doesn’t win you matches. 
“Look I’m very excited about the roster, the staff that the Queensland management have put together is great,” Smith said. 
“Obviously we have some very good players within the squad. 
“I’ve been a part of squads that have been fantastic but haven’t fulfilled what their aim has been at the start of the year, so it’s up to the players to listen and take on board what the coaches are saying and directing. 
“But ultimately it’s the players that need to be doing the job on the training field and in games. 
“Do I have a prediction for the end of the season? No I don’t. But I do expect good things from the Reds.” Queensland Reds coach Nick Stiles confronts the media at Ballymore. Source: News Corp Australia 
Smith won’t feature in this weekend’s inaugural Brisbane Tens tournament, but remains a chance to feature in the Reds’ trial against the Melbourne Rebels on Tuesday at Ballymore. 
Meanwhile, Reds coach Stiles said he was extremely disappointed in Higginbotham’s actions that led to him being charged for one count each of assaulting police and being found in a police establishment without a lawful cause after an incident in Brisbane’s Fortitude Valley at around 1.30am on Sunday. 
“I’m extremely disappointed and extremely annoyed,” Stiles said. 
“There are so many good things I’d prefer to talk about with the Reds and here we are talking about an incident with a player. 
“I’m really frustrated when this day should have been all about the arrival of George Smith, one of the great Wallabies, in Reds colours for the first time.” View All Comments The latest sports news, in your inbox daily. Email
